Since you have a strong auditing/finance background, you might choose one of these lenses: Conceptual understanding: Focus on what the math means, not necessarily every equation. Technical depth: Aim to follow most of the equations, understand how they hang together. Crossâ€‘disciplinary insights: How does the mathematics tie to history of AI, business/finance impact, and ethics? Choose which combination youâ€™ll emphasise. Allocate time by chapter difficulty. Reviews note that the book grows more mathematically dense. Goodreads +2 Salonenâ€™s Views on Life & Business +2 For example: allocate shorter time for narrative/history chapters, more for the deeply mathematical ones. Use a timer or goal (e.g., â€œ30 min plus 10 min reflectionâ€) per reading session. 2. Active reading strategies While reading, apply techniques to deepen comprehension and retention: Annotation / margin notes. Write down what the equation is doing in words (â€œThis shows how gradient descent moves down the loss surfaceâ€). Mark terms youâ€™ll revisit (â€œWhat exactly is the biasâ€‘variance tradeâ€‘off?â€) Concept map or flow diagram. As you finish a chapter, draw a diagram linking key concepts: e.g., â€œlinear algebra â†’ matrix representations of dataâ€, â€œcalculus â†’ optimization for trainingâ€, â€œprobability â†’ generalization/overfittingâ€. Equation translation. For a given formula, try to say in plain language what it means: e.g., â€œThe update rule changes weights by a small amount proportional to the negative gradient of lossâ€. That will help you connect the abstract math to intuition. Pause and reflect every 20â€‘30 pages. Ask: â€œWhat is the â€˜big ideaâ€™ of this section?â€ â€œWhat historical milestone or researcher is being spotlighted, and how does that link to the math?â€ â€œHow might this apply to a realâ€‘world decision system (e.g., in finance or auditing)?â€ Keep a running glossary of terms and symbols. Especially if youâ€™re not routinely doing ML math, youâ€™ll appreciate having a goâ€‘to reference of symbols, Greek letters, matrices, etc. 3. Analytical lenses / deeper questions After or while reading, here are additional lenses you can apply to analyse the book and its claims: Historical context lens. The book situates the math within the history of machine learning: perceptrons, neural networks, deep learning. Anil Ananthaswamy +2 PenguinRandomhouse.com +2 Ask: â€œWhich earlier math/algorithms still underpin modern advances?â€ and â€œWhat changed (technologically or mathematically) to make deep learning viable?â€ Mathâ€‘toâ€‘application lens. For each major mathematical concept (e.g., eigenvectors/principal component analysis, support vector machines, backpropagation) ask: â€œWhat realâ€‘world problem does this address?â€ â€œWhat are the limitations of this approach (e.g., in finance, auditing, risk)?â€ Ethics / audit/decisionâ€‘framework lens. Since you come from auditing/finance, you might emphasise: â€œHow does understanding the math help me evaluate AI decisionâ€‘systems (bias, transparency, risk)?â€ â€œWhat audit controls, risk frameworks, or governance mechanisms should accompany systems built on these algorithms?â€ Limitations & future lens. The book addresses how simple math ideas (some centuries old) undergird modern systemsâ€”but also their limitations. PenguinRandomhouse.com +1 Ask: â€œWhere might the mathematical foundations still be inadequate?â€ â€œWhat are emerging mathematical/methodological gaps?â€ Interdisciplinary lens. The author reflects on whether the same math might underpin natural intelligence and artificial intelligence. PenguinRandomhouse.com +1 Explore: â€œWhat analogies or divergences exist between human cognition and ML algorithms?â€ â€œWhat can auditing or riskâ€‘management learn from that parallel?â€ 4. Postâ€‘reading / consolidation Once youâ€™ve finished the book (or as you go), these steps will deepen your retention and transfer into your professional/academic context: Summarise each chapter in one paragraph. Capture key takeâ€‘aways, major equations, and historic milestone discussed. Select 3â€‘5 â€œtransferâ€ questions and answer them. For example: â€œHow would the biasâ€‘variance tradeâ€‘off matter in an AI decisionâ€‘system for loan approvals?â€ â€œIf a neuralâ€‘networkâ€‘based risk model fails, which mathâ€‘based assumptions might have broken?â€ â€œHow might governance frameworks account for matrix algebra or optimisation steps behind the system?â€ Create a â€œconversation sheetâ€ or list of discussion questions. Useful if you might share the book with colleagues or in a reading group. E.g., â€œWas the authorâ€™s treatment of support vector machines adequately deep for auditing a classification system?â€ Map your professional role to the math. Since youâ€™re an auditor in the finance function: consider how knowledge of linear algebra, optimisation, and probability might improve your ability to audit AI/ML systems in the bank. Perhaps list â€œtop 3 risks in ML systemsâ€ and trace them back to mathematical roots (e.g., overâ€‘fitting = high variance in probabilistic sense; data representation = matrix condition number issues; optimisation convergence = local minima). Teach or explain to others. One of the best ways to understand is to teach: maybe prepare a short 10â€‘minute presentation for your team summarising the bookâ€™s math and its relevance to your organisation. Follow up with further reading. The book gives a strong foundation; you might then follow up with more specialised texts or papers on e.g.Â optimisation in ML, fairness in AI, audit of ML systems. Example: the concept of doubleâ€‘descent in modern ML is referenced in recent research (which the book might mention historically). arXiv +1 Reflect periodically. After 1â€¯month, revisit your notes/glossary and see what remains clear or what needs reinforcement. Use â€œWhat surprised me?â€ â€œWhich equation still confuses me?â€ â€œWhich concept do I now use in my work or anticipate using?â€ 5. Reading schedule suggestion (customised) Given the content and your schedule, hereâ€™s a suggested 4â€‘week plan (you can adjust to your pace): Week Focus Activities Weekâ€¯1 Chapters 1â€“3 (Foundations: math prerequisites, early ML) Quick read of history + major math tools; make glossary; pause after each chapter to summarise. Weekâ€¯2 Chapters 4â€“7 (Classic algorithms: SVMs, PCA, perceptrons, neural networks) Spend more time on the math; for each algorithm: write in own words how it works; what problem it solves. Weekâ€¯3 Chapters 8â€“10 (Deep learning, modern architectures, largeâ€‘languageâ€‘model context) Tie the older math to modern systems; pick one modern architecture described and trace back to the math foundations. Weekâ€¯4 Chapters 11â€“12 + Afterword (Implications, ethics, future directions) Focus on the business/ethical/professional implications; prepare your â€œtransferâ€ questions; summarise whole book; create a 10â€‘minute shareable summary for your team. 6. Special considerations given you (Dante, auditor, professional) Audit lens: When reading algorithm descriptions, ask: â€œIf a bank uses this algorithm in credit scoring or risk modelling, what audit steps or controls would I design?â€ Example: trace data â†’ matrix representation â†’ optimisation â†’ output; at each step ask: â€œWhat could go wrong?â€ Mathematical comfort: If you find the math sections dense, donâ€™t skip, but you can treat the full derivation as â€œnice to knowâ€ rather than mandatory; focus on the intuition and the major result (as some reviewers suggest the notation may be challenging for nonâ€‘mathâ€‘specialists). Goodreads +1 Professional application: Because you handle finance and risk, you might pay special attention to chapters/sections where the author discusses decision systems, classification, bias/variance, highâ€‘dimensional data, generalisation, etc., and think about parallels in financial modelling (credit, fraud detection, capital modelling). Integration with your learning goals: Since you like structured, formal formatting (youâ€™ve said you prefer formal formatting for papers), you might build your chapter summaries or concept maps in a formal style (e.g., heading, subheading, definition, theorem statement (if applicable), application note, audit implication). Sharing & conversation: Consider organising a short reading group with colleagues (e.g., risk modelling team) so you can discuss key points and how the math links to your institutionâ€™s AI/ML initiatives. Teaching or leading the conversation will deepen your own understanding. If you like, I can prepare a readingâ€‘guide workbook for this book: e.g., chapterâ€‘byâ€‘chapter key concepts, questions for reflection, auditâ€‘/professionalâ€‘focus prompts, glossary of equations/symbols, maybe even a slideâ€‘deck template you can use with colleagues. Would you like me to build that?

title: Reccomendations for How to Read and Analyze Why Machines Learn
text:
Analysis
The first response gave me a broad collection of external impressions of Why Machines Learn: The Elegant Math Behind Modern AI. It summarized reviews from different sources like Goodreads, Penguin Random House, and other critics, helping me understand how the book has been received and what readers tend to emphasizeâ€”its clear narrative, historical grounding, and the balance between accessibility and technical rigor. That perspective let me see how other readers interpreted the authorâ€™s main goal: explaining the mathematical beauty behind machine learning without making it feel abstract. It also gave me a sense of where the book succeeds and where it might challenge readers, especially those not deeply trained in math. The second response shifted from what others say to how I should personally engage with the book. Rather than focusing on opinions, it outlined strategies for reading, understanding, and analyzing the text through structured methodsâ€”like mapping equations to intuition, reflecting after each chapter, and connecting the math to real-world applications in auditing or finance. It felt more practical and individualized, guiding me to move from passive comprehension to active analysis. Compared to the first response, which provided outside perspectives, the second emphasized process and self-reflection, helping me turn the book from something to read into something to work with critically and professionally.

title: Selecting Classes
text:
I am a junior at the Univeristy of Pennsylvania majoring in political science and completing a minor in legal studies & history. What classes do you reccomedn that I take and why do you reccomend that I take them.
Outstanding classes for a junior at the University of Pennsylvania majoring in political science and minoring in legal studies & history include foundational, thought-provoking, and career-relevant courses from both disciplines. Several specific courses are recommended for a strong academic and practical foundation, as well as electives that allow deep exploration of interests, career aspirations, or graduate school preparation.[1][2][3][4]



PSCI 1601: Political Ideas: Left, Right, and Center â€” This class helps students grasp ideological currents shaping American and Western political thought since WWII and is crucial for understanding todayâ€™s political debates.[2]
PSCI 1602: Political Action and Dissent â€” Focuses on political theory and activism, engaging students with concepts of civil disobedience, just authority, and the philosophy behind political movements â€” an essential perspective for law and policy.[2]
PSCI Comparative Politics & International Relations electives â€” These broaden understanding of different political systems and global affairs, which is valuable for both political science and legal studies.[2]





LGST 1010: Law and Social Values â€” Provides essential training in legal reasoning and the history of law as a social institution, including contract law fundamentals.[4][1]
HIST 1119: History of American Law to 1877 â€” Examines U.S. legal foundations, constitutional creation, law and social change, and civil rights, offering historical depth to contemporary issues.[3][1]
HIST 1169: History of American Law since 1877 â€” Delves into legal developments post-Reconstruction, linking historical legal decisions to todayâ€™s policies and institutions.[1]
Foundations of Law (such as HIST 1201) â€” Provides philosophical perspectives on law, including justice, fairness, and the origins of legal systems.[3]





Public Opinion and American Democracy (e.g., PSCI 230) â€” Valuable for students interested in the intersection of public attitudes, government, and democratic institutions.[5]
Human Rights/Comparative Politics â€” Widens focus, crossing legal, historical, and political issues globally.[6][2]
Judicial Politics or American Constitutionalism â€” Bridges political science and legal studies, focusing on courts, judicial behavior, and constitutional frameworks.[7]





American Political Thought â€” Explores how political theory has shaped American governance and law.[3]
Law and Economics â€” Merges legal studies with foundations in economic theory, vital for careers in government, business, or law.[3]
Courses such as Free Speech and Censorship, Bodies, Race and Rights, or U.S. Politics and Society since the 1960s â€” These connect legal, social, and historical debates that are crucial for well-rounded policy analysis, advocacy, or graduate work.[3]





They provide robust training in research, writing, analysis, and debate, all essential for advanced study, law school, or policy work.[1][2]
They expose students to diverse perspectives on American and international political thought, history, and law.[1][2][3]
Many are taught by leading faculty and have reputations for rigorous instruction and engaging discussions, making them both challenging and rewarding.[4]

Taking this blend of foundational, theoretical, and specialized courses will create a well-rounded record, offering strong preparation for law school, graduate programs, government, advocacy, or policy-oriented careers.[4][2][1][3]

title: Selecting Classes
text:
Second Prompt
Please provide me information regarding the difficulty and the course quality ratings of the courses you provided me with in the previous response.
Many of the courses previously recommended at the University of Pennsylvania are regarded as high quality, though some require substantial reading and a strong analytical approach. Here is an overview of student-reported difficulty and course quality ratings for the main courses mentioned:

PSCI 1601: Political Ideas: Left, Right, and Center

Difficulty: Generally viewed as moderately challenging, depending on the professor and studentâ€™s background in political philosophy. Similar courses in the department are noted for fair grading but substantial reading and writing requirements.[1][2]
Course Quality: Students praise these coursesâ€™ relevance and engaging teaching, although not always the easiest electives. Classes like PSCI 230 (â€œPublic Opinion and American Democracyâ€), taught by Michelle Margolis, are specifically highlighted as â€œvery informative, super interestingâ€ with fair grading and significant workload.[2]



LGST 1010: Law and Social Values

Difficulty: The course is described as rigorous, especially in sections taught by professors who model exams after law school hypotheticals, requiring careful reading and novel application of course concepts. Still, it is foundational for those interested in law and considered manageable with strong analytical and writing skills.[3][4]
Course Quality: LGST 1010 is seen as well-structured, with a reputation for teaching students to â€œthink like a lawyerâ€ even at the undergraduate level. Course reviews highlight its engaging approach to legal theory and excellent preparation for more advanced legal coursework.[5][4]



HIST 1119: History of American Law to 1877

Difficulty: This seminar-style class is frequently reported as enjoyable and rewarding, with a workload that includes assigned readings, participation, and essay-based assessments. Students find it possible to earn strong grades with consistent work.[6][7][8]
Course Quality: HIST 1119 receives enthusiastic feedback, with students describing the professor as engaging and the material as â€œthoroughly enjoyable.â€ It blends legal and historical analysis in ways that appeal to those interested in both fields.[9][6]

title: First Car Reccomendation
text:
What reccomendations would you have for first cars for a high school kid who just got their license.
For a high school kid who just got their license, the best first car recommendations focus on safety, reliability, affordability, and ease of driving. Here are some solid options:



Look for cars with good crash-test ratings and modern safety features like airbags, anti-lock brakes, and stability control.
Avoid high-performance or overly large vehicles that might be harder for new drivers to handle.





Choose brands known for lasting a long time without expensive repairsâ€”Toyota, Honda, Hyundai, and Mazda are often top picks.
Older used cars from these brands can be very cost-effective while still reliable.





A used car in good condition around $5,000-$10,000 is often a smart choice for teens.
Economical vehicles that donâ€™t guzzle gas are great for keeping ongoing costs low.





Smaller cars or compact SUVs that are easy to maneuver and park help new drivers build confidence.





Toyota Corolla or Camry (used, reliable, good safety)
Honda Civic or Accord (dependable, affordable maintenance)
Mazda3 or Mazda CX-3 (fun to drive and reliable)
Hyundai Elantra or Sonata (great warranties and value)
Subaru Impreza (all-wheel drive for better handling)





Avoid flashy or expensive cars to reduce insurance costs.
Keep the car in good shape and maintain regular service to avoid breakdowns.
Consider safety accessories like backup cameras or parking sensors if possible.

Overall, the goal is a car thatâ€™s safe, reliable, not too expensive, and easy to drive for a new teen driver. This helps build good driving habits without extra stress or cost.

text:
Final Reflection
 Perplexity did a good job overall with the list, especially once I asked for the details like actual prices and safety ratings. At first, it gave me a solid general overview but didnâ€™t provide the numbers or ratings upfront, which felt like a missing piece. I had to push a bit to get that kind of concrete info, so it wasnâ€™t fully proactive in delivering everything at once. That said, Perplexity was quick and efficient at adapting when I asked for more specifics â€” diving into real-time data sources, pulling current used car prices, and referencing reputable safety ratings from IIHS and NHTSA, which was impressive. The inclusion of citations made the info transparent and trustworthy, a big plus compared to other AI tools that often just throw out unchecked facts. Perplexityâ€™s main strength is in combining web search and AI reasoning, so it can find accurate, up-to-date information and organize it well. But it doesnâ€™t fully anticipate every detail users might want right away without some nudging. The conversation feel was pretty natural, and Perplexity stayed on topic, which made the process smooth.
